meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>saw</radical> to cut down <radical>tree</radical>s to <kanji>construct</kanji> and <kanji>build</kanji> a building. The bamboo saw was crafted by a master bamboosmith, and cuts through trees with ease so you can quickly construct this new building.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>construct</kanji> and <kanji>build</kanji> this building, you hear a strange cheeping noise. Suddenly a <reading>chick</reading> (ちく) pops out of one of the logs you are building with. Then another, and another. You're surrounded by chicks! Is this because you used the magical(?) bamboo saw??

meaning_mnemonic: You should <radical>say</radical> "<radical>peace</radical>" before you <kanji>evaluate</kanji> a situation. That way everyone will know where you’re coming from. If you’re honest and say "peace" before you evaluate a situation out loud, everyone will know where you stand.
reading_mnemonic: When you say "peace," you end up making a really bad pun and you hear somebody say “<reading>Heyo</reading>!” (ひょう) You look at the people around you and try to <kanji>evaluate</kanji> who said heyo, but you can’t tell. You start talking again when somebody exclaims “That’s what she said” and another person shouts “Heyo!” once again, but you still can’t evaluate who’s saying these things.

meaning_mnemonic: You'll be put in a <radical>net</radical> if you try to <radical>say</radical> things with a <radical>knife</radical> — that's your <kanji>penalty</kanji>. You can't just go up to other people and say things with a knife out. That's why the police have to put you in a net, as a penalty.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>penalty</kanji> for breaking the law isn't over. Now that you're stuck in a net, you can't fight back when they hit you with <reading>bats</reading> (ばつ).

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>yoga</radical> is the <radical>correct</radical> way to go through <kanji>birth</kanji>. Birth isn't easy, but people keep telling you that yoga is the right way to prepare and actually do it.
reading_mnemonic: To prepare for giving <kanji>birth</kanji> you end up doing so much yoga outside that you get a really deep <reading>tan</reading> (たん).

kanji_to_vocab_info.reading: おたんじょうびおめでとう

meaning_mnemonic: The light of the <radical>moon</radical> is shining on a <radical>guard</radical> who’s been on duty all night. In fact, the moon light is making him so warm, he’s trying to <kanji>undress</kanji> and <kanji>escape</kanji>! Somebody stop him!
reading_mnemonic: You’re unable to stop the guard from <kanji>undress</kanji>ing and making his <kanji>escape</kanji>, so you decide to start throwing some <reading>darts</reading> (だつ) at him. Perhaps that’ll make him stop.

meaning_mnemonic: While riding on your <radical>scooter</radical>, you grow a <radical>mustache</radical> on top of the <radical>mustache</radical> you already have in order to <kanji>surpass</kanji> the people around you. You're in a scooter race and your mustache is the only thing keeping you in the lead, but someone else has a mustache too! So you grow another mustache to surpass them once again!
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly, something else manages to <kanji>surpass</kanji> you all. It's a <reading>ca</reading>r (か)! A car with two mustaches is also riding on a scooter and going way faster than you.

meaning_mnemonic: Can you look at the <radical>dirt</radical> and know which <radical>direction</radical> you need to go? Then you might be a <kanji>monk</kanji>. Monks have amazing skills like that. And I'm sure you've seen monks wandering around in lots of media. They don't need maps or smartphones. They just look at the dirt and let the earth guide them to where they need to be.
reading_mnemonic: You want to know the <kanji>monk</kanji>'s trick so you hide behind him for a while as he walks. Finally the monk stops, looks around, takes out a <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball and starts bowling in the dirt. The bowling ball rolls off, the monk follows it, and then heads off in that direction.

meaning_mnemonic: From the <radical>roof</radical>, an <radical>icicle</radical> falls and hits <radical>Wolverine</radical> in the <radical>forehead</radical>, and he has to go over to the <radical>stool</radical> to <kanji>lie down</kanji>. And eventually he goes to <kanji>sleep</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: While wolverine <kanji>sleep</kanji>s, he makes a horrible <reading>neigh</reading>ing (ね) sound. It's like there's a giant horse in his mouth screaming to get out! NEIGH NEIGH!

meaning_mnemonic: It may just be a <radical>roof</radical> over a <radical>bathtub</radical>, but this here is actually a <kanji>Shinto shrine</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: What god does this <kanji>Shinto shrine</kanji> hold? You see that "It's a-<reading>me-ya</reading> (みや)! (Mario!)"

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>kiss</radical> <kanji>each</kanji> and <kanji>every</kanji> one of your best pals to show them how much you love and care for them. You kiss each friend right on the mouth.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, <kanji>each</kanji> and <kanji>every</kanji> one of your best pals is of the <reading>cock</reading> (かく) variety. By that, I mean each of them is a rooster. Imagine kissing each cock on its beak.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cheap</radical> <radical>tree</radical> has a <kanji>plan</kanji>. A plan to stay cheap.
reading_mnemonic: The cheap tree's <kanji>plan</kanji> involves only buying <reading>an</reading>chovies (あん) and surviving on them. Good exposure to the sun and fresh water is too expensive. The tree plans to save money by eating anchovies.

meaning_mnemonic: You need your <radical>net</radical> to be <radical>straight</radical> before you <kanji>put</kanji> it on the ground and try to lure something into it. You put your net there to catch something, but if it's twisted or tangled, it won't be very effective.
reading_mnemonic: Then you decide to <kanji>put</kanji> <reading>chee</reading>se (ち) in your net. With a perfectly straight net and the cheese you put down as bait, there’s no way this fails. Success is all about how you put the net down and the cheese you put in it.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Dollar</radical>s and <radical>shellfish</radical> are used to pay <kanji>expense</kanji>s and <kanji>cost</kanji>s. Shellfish used to be used as currency, so they're like the coins that go with dollars.
reading_mnemonic: What is the biggest <kanji>expense</kanji> and <kanji>cost</kanji>? It's the <reading>hea</reading>t (ひ) bill.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> only uses the <radical>helicopter</radical> with the highest <kanji>value</kanji>. They choose to fly in only the very best, most valuable helicopter. That's why it's worth way more than the others. Actually, any helicopter they use goes up in value. That's the amazing effect of a good leader.
reading_mnemonic: To further increase the helicopter's <kanji>value</kanji>, the leader tied it to a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Wow, now it has the value of a helicopter and a car combined! For a total value of… Well, imagine for yourself what value the car adds.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>womb</radical> is a <radical>circle</radical> of <radical>power</radical> where a <kanji>force</kanji> of nature is formed. The womb has the power to create life. Life is a force of nature, and the circle of life starts in the womb.
reading_mnemonic: Now pretend you're the mother. You'll need all the <kanji>force</kanji> you can muster to bring that baby into the world, so you grab hold of your special <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) and slice it about in the air to give you the extra force you need.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> who knows how to use a <radical>bathtub</radical> will have to <kanji>manage</kanji> all the baths for the other Vikings. Vikings aren't so great with bathing... if you can get one Viking to figure it out he has to manage the rest of them.
reading_mnemonic: The poor Viking trying to <kanji>manage</kanji> all the others keeps having to confiscate <reading>a</reading>corns (えい). "You can't take baths in acorns and wood, it has to be water!" he shouts.

meaning_mnemonic: You can use a <radical>jackhammer</radical> to <kanji>indicate</kanji> and <kanji>show</kanji> someone where the prize is buried. You buried the prize to keep it safe, but the jackhammer is great at unearthing it. Jackhammers do a great job and show where the treasure lies. They indicate quite clearly where one needs to go.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, you're unearthing <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). He’s the treasure. For your soul. He’s here to show you that Jesus is still a hip and cool guy and he wants to <kanji>indicate</kanji> to you that having faith in Jesus and God and stuff is super rad. Jesus is all like, “Who has two thumbs and wants to <kanji>show</kanji> you the way of the Lord? This guy.”

meaning_mnemonic: You take all of your <radical>thread</radical> and <radical>allocate</radical> them into one place to <kanji>unite</kanji> them. With all your thread united and wrapped together, you're ready to <kanji>rule</kanji> and <kanji>govern</kanji> the world!
reading_mnemonic: You're busy trying to <kanji>unite</kanji> all of your thread, twisting and tying and wrapping, and suddenly you look at the ball in your hands and see <reading>とう</reading>きょう. You've united this thread into the shape of とうきょう. There are even little pins for all the famous neighborhoods and tourist spots. This is strange, because you don't remember putting them there.

meaning_mnemonic: Taking <radical>orders</radical> from a <radical>geoduck</radical> will place you into enemy <kanji>territory</kanji>. Geoducks make terrible commanders, so if you take orders from one, expect to end up in unknown territory, potentially even enemy territory. Be prepared.
reading_mnemonic: Not wanting to end up dead in enemy <kanji>territory</kanji>, you decide to escape this geoduck leader by getting on a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat and rowing your way outta there. The geoduck commander orders you to halt your escape, but you still get in your row boat and row away.

meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>tree</radical> resting atop your <radical>head</radical>, you devise a <kanji>plan</kanji>. The plan is actually for getting the bamboo tree off of your head. You’re trapped under it.
reading_mnemonic: But why is this bamboo tree so heavy? You look to each end of the bamboo and realize that there is a <reading>sack</reading> (さく) tied on each end. Each sack seems to be filled with heavy rocks. Looks like someone made a <kanji>plan</kanji> to trap you here. Now you have to devise a plan to escape!

meaning_mnemonic: The only <radical>flowers</radical> that the <radical>moon</radical> <radical>gladiator</radical>s will <radical>water</radical> are <kanji>wisteria</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Since they're on the moon, where did they get the <kanji>wisteria</kanji> from? Actually, from one of the points on earth that is nearest to the moon, Mt. <reading>Fuji</reading> (ふじ).

meaning_mnemonic: That <radical>scarecrow</radical> with the <radical>knife</radical> is the <kanji>vice</kanji> president. Yeah, I know how he looks, and I'm pretty sure he does some murdering on the <kanji>side</kanji>, but you didn't hear that from me.
reading_mnemonic: It's the <kanji>vice</kanji> president's turn to speak at the podium and he just clears his throat and yells, "<reading>F**k</reading> (ふく) you!" to the crowd, holding up his knife. They cheer.

meaning_mnemonic: There's an <radical>arrow</radical> in a <radical>turkey</radical> that you can <radical>see</radical> in your <kanji>view</kanji>. The turkey seems to be viewing you too, from afar.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>view</kanji> the turkey, Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) suddenly comes into your view too. He towers over the injured turkey, leans down, and... pulls the arrow out!?

meaning_mnemonic: A great <radical>leader</radical> can look <radical>straight</radical> at something and know its <kanji>value</kanji>. That social media site? 44 billion dollars. That job position? 50k a year. A four-day work week? Um… sorry, no, there's no value there. See? Leaders can see straight to the heart of matters to grasp something's true value.
reading_mnemonic: One thing your leader knows has great <kanji>value</kanji> is <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). Say goodbye to your days of casually snacking on cheesy treats from the conbini, because your leader's decided the value of cheese is going up 1000%!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> is like an <radical>escalator</radical> you use to <kanji>suck</kanji> and <kanji>inhale</kanji> things into your body.
reading_mnemonic: Use this mouth ability to <kanji>suck</kanji> <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (きゅう) into your mouth. Cucumbers are shaped like cylinders so you can suck them into your mouth like this. Just as nature intended.

meaning_mnemonic: Lying in the <radical>dirt</radical>, a <radical>drunkard</radical> puts her <radical>mouth</radical> to the <radical>ground</radical> to understand the <kanji>region</kanji>. She loves to know all the regional differences among wines and other alcohols, and to her there's no better way to do this than putting her mouth on the ground and literally tasting each region.
reading_mnemonic: Turns out she thinks everything from this <kanji>region</kanji> is <reading>icky</reading> (いき). In fact, to the drunkard, every region tastes icky and gross. You don't have the heart to tell her it's the dirt and ground, not the region itself, that tastes icky…

meaning_mnemonic: “Bring in the <radical>next</radical> <radical>woman</radical> so that I may examine her <kanji>figure</kanji>!” We’re holding auditions for a commercial and we need to find a woman with a nice figure. The last woman was no good, so bring in the next one.
reading_mnemonic: The next woman comes in and you examine her <kanji>figure</kanji>. The figure you've been searching for! It just happens to belong to a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) woman. But she's soft, fluffy, and round. The perfect figure!

meaning_mnemonic: If someone gets under the <radical>canopy</radical> over your <radical>heart</radical> you should <kanji>respond</kanji> to them.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>respond</kanji> and it turns out it was to the <reading>王</reading> (おう).

meaning_mnemonic: Pointing your <radical>fingers</radical> to the <radical>sun</radical> is the <radical>correct</radical> way to <kanji>present</kanji> yourself or offer to <kanji>submit</kanji> your ideas. You're really just raising your hand. And when you want to present yourself, your ideas, or offer anything, the correct way is to raise your fingers to the sun. You definitely learned this in school.
reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>present</kanji> your show and tell of <reading>ta</reading>ter tots (てい) to the class. You raise your hand, the teacher calls on you, and you <kanji>submit</kanji> the tater tots for her and the class's approval. "Oh my!" the teacher exclaims, "I hope you brought enough tater tots to present to the whole class!" You raise your hand once more to the sky, and in it you submit a whole tray of tater tots!

meaning_mnemonic:
You use your <radical>fingers</radical> in the game of <radical>football</radical> to <kanji>aid</kanji> and <kanji>assist</kanji> the other players. And when you smash your fingers in football, you need to get some aid yourself.

If you're from the UK, just imagine someone kicking or stomping on your fingers instead.
reading_mnemonic: When you need <kanji>aid</kanji> for your football wrecked fingers you can't help but feel like it's the <reading>en</reading>d (えん) for you. Your fingers hurt so much, you don't even want the nice nurses to aid you.

meaning_mnemonic: See all those <radical>icicle</radical>s to the <radical>dog</radical>'s left? Good thing they all fell on his left, or he would've been in a terrible <kanji>condition</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: What saved the dog's <kanji>condition</kanji> was none other than <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the local farmhand. He constantly keeps an eye on the dog's condition, including any dangerously sharp icicles that could descend on him.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a great <radical>ability</radical> because your <radical>heart</radical> gives you the <kanji>appearance</kanji> of a superhuman. Your heart is really strong and powerful, fuelling your body to the best of its ability. All this together gives you the appearance of someone in top condition.
reading_mnemonic: While you may have the <kanji>appearance</kanji> of someone who is super strong, powerful, and awesome, you do have one shortcoming. You don’t know how to <reading>tie</reading> (たい) a tie. Actually, you don’t even know how to tie your shoes, let alone your tie. How embarrassing.

meaning_mnemonic: You use the <radical>power</radical> of your <radical>mouth</radical> to spit <radical>shellfish</radical> at people as a form of <kanji>congratulations</kanji>! In fact, you yell "CONGRATULATIONS!" as the shellfish come pouring out of your powerful mouth.
reading_mnemonic: When you say <kanji>congratulations</kanji> like this, you look just like a <reading>ga</reading>rgoyle (が). You're crouching down, your mouth wide open, just like a stone gargoyle.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>ground</radical> of the <radical>rice paddy</radical> is a <radical>treasure</radical>. As you pull it out of the mucky ground, you can feel your life force being<kanji>renew</kanji>ed.
reading_mnemonic: Just as you were getting accustomed to this life <kanji>renew</kanji>ing treasure, <reading>こう</reading>いち comes out of nowhere, stealing your treasure and running off with it.

meaning_mnemonic: Inside the <radical>building</radical> is the <radical>Winter</radical> <radical>Cow</radical>. You need to see it, so you go inside. It is deep down in there, and you'll have to <kanji>descend</kanji> to reach it.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>descend</kanji> to the bottom and there it is, the Winter Cow. You walk up to the cow, and it swings its head back to see you. Instead of a cow's face, it's <reading>こう</reading>いち's face.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>clothes</radical> radical and the <kanji>clothes</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Surprising!
reading_mnemonic: An <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) sees a pile of your <kanji>clothes</kanji> and lays an <reading>e</reading>gg (え) in them. The eagle’s egg needs a soft warm place to incubate, and your pile of clothes is the perfect place.

meaning_mnemonic: You have something to <radical>say</radical>, so you <radical>stand</radical> up, throw in the <radical>towel</radical>, and shout: "I <kanji>GIVE UP</kanji>!" The stand radical looks a little weird in this kanji, probably because you're all tired and ready to give up.
reading_mnemonic: What's making you want to <kanji>give up</kanji>? Well, there's <reading>a killer</reading> (あきら) behind you who's threatening to kill you if you don't.

meaning_mnemonic: A mix of <radical>spirit</radical> and <radical>reason</radical> helped you invent the <kanji>sleeve</kanji>. Your spirit told you your arms were uncomfortable, stuck to your sides under that shirt. Reason told you that maybe, just maybe, if you made holes for your arms something good would come out of it. And that's how sleeves were born!
reading_mnemonic: And without these <kanji>sleeve</kanji>s, your arms would be <reading>so de</reading>ad (そで). They'd be all exposed and defenseless!
